sentences: Zhōu Wénzhōng; July 28, 1923 – October 25, 2019) was a Chinese American composer of contemporary classical music.
He emigrated in 1946 to the United States and received his music training at the New England Conservatory and Columbia University.
Early years in China =
section: == Life == | === Early years in China ===

sentences: Qin music, in particular, has proved fertile ground for his future exploration.
section: == Life == | === Early years in China ===

sentences: Chou attended Guangxi University during 1942–44 and managed to find time to compose music on his own and to educate himself about western culture through reading library books despite the nightly air raids and his civil engineering study.
section: == Life == | === Early years in China ===

sentences: Chou had to move again in 1944 and continued his study in Chongqing University where he received his B.S. degree in civil engineering.
section: == Life == | === Early years in China ===

sentences: In 1946, Chou turned down a scholarship in architecture at Yale University in order to pursue music, studying with Nicolas Slonimsky at the New England Conservatory and with Edgard Varèse and Otto Luening in New York.
section: == Life == | === Turning point – Music study and teaching in the United States ===

sentences: In a conversation with Frank J. Oteri published on NewMusicBox in 2013, Chou described the difficulties he had at that time:
section: == Life == | === Turning point – Music study and teaching in the United States ===

sentences: For more than a week, I stayed in my room.
section: == Life == | === Turning point – Music study and teaching in the United States ===

sentences: Chou studied composition with Otto Luening at Columbia University and from 1949–1954, took lessons privately with Edgard Varèse who became a lifelong mentor and friend.
section: == Life == | === Turning point – Music study and teaching in the United States ===

sentences: Synthesizing western and eastern sounds has been a pursuit of Chou's throughout his life.
section: == Life == | === Turning point – Music study and teaching in the United States ===

sentences: During his early compositional years in New York, one experience changed Chou's perspective on how to incorporate different cultural elements.
section: == Life == | === Turning point – Music study and teaching in the United States ===

sentences: To re-learn and to interpret his own tradition, in 1955, Chou spent two years researching classical Chinese music and drama with a grant from the Rockefeller Foundation.
section: == Life == | === Turning point – Music study and teaching in the United States ===

sentences: To re-learn and to interpret his own tradition, in 1955, Chou spent two years researching classical Chinese music and drama with a grant from the Rockefeller Foundation.
section: == Life == | === Turning point – Music study and teaching in the United States ===

sentences: He became a naturalized citizen of the U.S. in 1958.
section: == Life == | === Turning point – Music study and teaching in the United States ===

sentences: In 1954, he became the first technical assistant at Columbia's Electronic Music Laboratory and was concurrently appointed director of a research project on Chinese music and drama.
section: == Academic career ==

sentences: In 1978, Chou Wen-chung established the Center for US-China Arts Exchange at Columbia University to promote mutual understanding between the two countries through the channel of culture.
section: == Career as cultural ambassador ==

sentences: It was the first organization to address the need to re-connect leaders in the arts in China and the United States after diplomatic ties had been severed for thirty years.
section: == Career as cultural ambassador ==

sentences: In the 1990s the Center's purview expanded to include programs focused on the arts of ethnic nationalities in Yunnan province and relevant issues of environmental preservation.
section: == Career as cultural ambassador ==

sentences: Ultimately, he sought not so much to amalgamate the divergent Eastern and Western traditions as to internalize and transcend contemporary idioms and techniques to create an intimately personal style that reflects a genuine, modern sensibility.
section: == Music career ==

sentences: Chou Wen-chung was a member of the American Academy of Arts and Letters and in 2001, he was named Officier des Ordre des Arts et des Lettres by the French Ministry of Culture.
section: == Music career ==

sentences: In 2018, the Xinghai Conservatory of Music in Guangzhou opened the Chou Wen-chung Music Research Center to carry on the composer's legacy and initiate projects in support of contemporary music.
section: == Music career ==

sentences: He was awarded an honorary doctorate from the New England Conservatory in 2019.
section: == Music career ==

sentences: Representative compositions from this period are Landscapes (1949), All in the Spring Wind (1952–1953), And the Fallen Petals (1954), and Willow Are New (1957).

sentences: Beginning in the late 1950s, Chou began to experiment with variable modes in his compositions.
section: == Composition styles and developments == | === Mature period ===

sentences: The piece metaphor (1960) marks the beginning of Chou's middle period when Chou utilized the variable modes as a compositional method to pitch organization.
section: == Composition styles and developments == | === Mature period ===

sentences: Later, Chou applied the modes to other works such as Cursive (1963), Pien (1966), and Yun (1969).
section: == Composition styles and developments == | === Mature period ===

section: == Composition styles and developments == | === Mature period ===

sentences: Ideogram is another evolutionary concept Chou experimented with while attempting to synthesize western and eastern elements and render Chinese sounds through western instruments.
section: == Composition styles and developments == | === Mature period ===

sentences: Chou is an accomplished calligrapher and after years of practicing the various styles and scripts of Chinese calligraphic writings, Chou began to see the parallels in the art of calligraphy and music.
section: == Composition styles and developments == | === Mature period ===

sentences: Chou compares the ink flow to the density of the music and experimented with the ideograms of cursive style writing in the piece Cursive in 1963.
section: == Composition styles and developments == | === Mature period ===

sentences: Some notable compositions are Beijing in the Mist (1986), Echoes from the Gorge (1996), Windswept Peaks (1994), Concerto for Violincello and Orchestra (1991), and Clouds (1998).

sentences: Chou wrote his second string quartet, Streams (2003) in response to Bach's Art of Fugue, which was commissioned by the Brentano String Quartet.
section: == Composition styles and developments == | === Mature period ===

sentences: In 2007, the gayageum master, Yi Ji-young, commissioned him to write a work for gayageum and an ensemble of traditional Korean instruments.
section: == Composition styles and developments == | === Mature period ===

sentences: Her group, Contemporary Music Ensemble of Korea (CMEK) premiered Eternal Pine in 2008.
section: == Composition styles and developments == | === Mature period ===

sentences: Chou wrote a version for western instruments, Ode to Eternal Pine (2009), for the New York New Music Ensemble (NYNME) and a version for traditional Chinese instruments, Sizhu Eternal Pine (2012; his first and only work for a full ensemble of Chinese instruments), for the Taipei Chinese Orchestra.
section: == Composition styles and developments == | === Mature period ===
